5* The NAEB training program, and all the rest of the seminars and work¬
shops, are useful only to a point. Until there are trained managers
who can agree on some kind of a common denominator principle with
respect to the shape and substance of educational television, the
whole thing will continue to wallow in confusion.
6. Temporary agencies are becoming permanent, and the duplication already
noted, is wasting money. There should be mergers of function and
perhaps elimination of some presently existing agencies.
7• Throughout the whole national picture there is too much jealousy,
too much individual ego concern, soma intellectual snobbishness, a
natural tendency for various agencies to perpetuate themselves whether
or not their services are really required, and an illusion that travel
and motion are synonymous with accomplishment and progress.
8. Seminars, workshops, and ’’group-thinks" can become a vast waste of
time. "Group dynamics" is not the problem nor-can a set of working
techniques and approaches very well be evolved from group discussion.
The real problem is for those who are motivated to get into educational,
television to learn the realistic requirements and procedures for
operating a station. A few competent people need to review all of
j the present data, discard much of it, integrate the remainder, stipu¬
late some standard operating procedures and concepts which give seme
promise of producing successful results—and then systematically
teach and train prospective station operators in the facts of life.
9© Obviously there is a need to group all of the various agencies and
organisations either into a cooperative working arrangement with the
elements of cooperation stipulated or to reduce the agencies in
number and consolidate functions in whole or in part<> Such an
"umbrella" organisation would doubtless be more appealing to any
foundations which might be approached for further support. Th®
difficulties in creating an "umbrella" organisation or even a merger
©f two agencies are apparent. There is a natural disposition for
each agency to consider itself "unique" and "sovereign" and relatively
indispensable o It will take some very hard-boiled thinking and some
genuine sacrifice if the logical conclusion is attained after being
recognised.
